snippet: A report predicted that the world oil benchmark price over the next few years would slip from a 2012 average of $112 a barrel to $92 a barrel in 2017.
abstract: Energy Department predicts domestic oil production will continue to soar for years to come, scaling to levels not seen in nearly half a century by 2016; predicts increase in United States production will contribute to decline in world oil benchmark price over the next few years to $92 a barrel in 2017 from 2012 average of $112 a barrel, which should translate into lower prices at pump for consumers.

byline.original: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS and STANLEY REED
byline.contributor: Clifford Krauss reported from Houston and Stanley Reed from London.

lead_paragraph: A report predicted that the world oil benchmark price over the next few years would slip from a 2012 average of $112 a barrel to $92 a barrel in 2017.

headline.main: Surge Seen in U.S. Oil Output, Lowering Gasoline Prices
headline.print_headline: U.S. Oil Production Projected to Surge, Leading to Lower Prices at Gas Pump
